name: Hal Mcfann
history:
HAL MCFANN

Callsign: THOTH

Affiliation: Union (Auxiliary / Intelligence Track)

Background: High-End Hacker → Union Lancer

Homeworld: HOUSES (Diasporan Orbital Habitat)

Backstory

Hal McFann learned early that information was the only currency that never devalued.

Born and raised in the HOUSES—densely packed orbital habitats where corporate enclaves, data havens, and black-market servers overlap—Hal grew up surrounded by systems that were never meant to be secure, only profitable. He showed an early aptitude for code, slipping past parental locks and habitat firewalls before he was old enough to legally own a terminal. By his late teens, Hal had abandoned legitimate work entirely, surviving instead as a high-end freelance hacker, specializing in data extraction, system intrusion, and digital counterintelligence.

His alias on the mesh was THOTH, named after an ancient Terran god of knowledge, writing, and secrets. Under that name, Hal became known for impossible jobs: ghosting corporate AIs without triggering alarms, extracting sealed data from hardened black boxes, and rewriting reality in bureaucratic systems so cleanly that no one realized anything had changed. He didn’t just steal information—he curated it.

That reputation eventually drew attention from the wrong people.

During what was supposed to be a routine contract, Hal uncovered evidence of a covert operation tied to an extra-legal paramilitary group operating under the cover of a Union-adjacent contractor. The data wasn’t just valuable—it was dangerous, implicating powerful interests in violations of the First Contact Accords and colonial autonomy laws. When Hal tried to sell the data, the buyers didn’t negotiate.

They hunted him.

Hal survived only because Union Intelligence found him first.

Rather than disappear him—or recruit him quietly—Union made an offer: full amnesty, citizenship upgrades, and Lancer training in exchange for service. Union didn’t need another soldier; they needed someone who understood systems from the inside out, someone who could fight wars that didn’t always involve bullets.

Hal accepted.

Lancer training was brutal, disorienting, and nothing like the quiet certainty of code. But Hal adapted. Where others learned battlefield tactics, he learned to read the war itself—electronic warfare, NHP behavior patterns, mech telemetry, and enemy command structures. In the cockpit, Hal’s mind treated combat like a living network, every hostile unit a node waiting to be exploited.

He kept the callsign THOTH.

Now deployed as a Union Lancer, Hal McFann walks a thin line between idealism and cynicism. He believes in Union’s principles—but never forgets how easily systems lie. He follows orders, but always reads between the lines. Somewhere out there are people who still want him erased, and secrets he never fully sold.

If war is information, then Thoth intends to control the narrative.

systems.flavorDescription: Precise interaction with built and natural environments, soft targets, and hazardous materials is part of the daily routine for support-class mechs. This is made possible by manipulators – added multi-digit “hands” with haptic sensors.
The GMS Type-3 Projected Shield traps and denies incoming projectiles by projecting an aggressive, superpositional anti-ballistic barrier.

This system upgrade appears to add auxiliary INSTINCT systems that are capable of autonomous operation independent of the base INSTINCT rig, increasing the efficacy of systemic invasion attempts. Pilots report unnerving low-frequency humming when this tech is installed without the parent rig.

weapon.flavorDescription: The autopod is a small antipersonnel weapon apparently devised by HORUS communocyphers to continue offensive action in the event of its operator’s death. Each unit is, in theory, governed by a spur of INSTINCT’s protomind. No new models have been encountered since DHIYED, and all extant versions of the Autopod are to be considered extremely dangerous as the INSTINCT code powering their onboard protominds is likely to have corrupted further since their creation.

Much like GMS mechs, GMS weapons are reliable galactic standards, made using interchangeable parts and built to withstand almost any conditions. There are three lines currently in production.
The Type-III (T-3) line is made up of heavy weapons, ordnance, and other exotic, specialized, or massive weapons. A broad classification, the T-3 range includes conventional-kinetic anti-materiel rifles, super-rapid cycling pulse rifles, missile racks, cannons, and drone nexuses – “hive”style launchers that serve as miniature factory, hangar, and deployment systems for portable drones. The classification also includes the fearsome “segment knife”, a system that uses flash-printing to produce disposable edged weapons in a vicinity around the user.

bondPowers.name: Metalbloom
bondPowers.description: For the rest of this scene, you cannot roll less than a 10 on any skill checks involving the use or understanding of technology. Treat any d20 result of a 9 or lower as a 10.

bondAnswers: Part of your body that you built yourself, lovingly tinkered with.
minorIdeal: I created a new object, organization, or alliance, or mended one that was broken.

weapons.flavorDescription: Light signature weapons might be oversized revolvers, braces of pistols, and submachine guns.
Medium signature weapons are assault rifles, shotguns, pack-fed lasers, or disruption guns.

gear.flavorDescription: A reactive, synthetic polymer with advanced qualities, infoskin bonds quickly to real skin and hair. Once applied, it responds to electronic signals delivered by linked software, rapidly changing its color and texture – even contorting and distorting its form – allowing wearers to make minor changes to their appearance. With infoskin, it’s a simple matter to alter facial features, hair color, or makeup patterns.

A portable – if bulky – omninet terminal that allows for communication, data transfer, and limited hot-spotting. Omnihooks are extremely valuable, although most mech squads have at least one. Tuning an omnihook requires a high level of skill, so they are usually mounted or carried by designated operators.

A powered third arm mounted on a bracket on the hardsuit. Tertiary arms are powered and controlled using the same neural bridge processes that allow hardsuits to respond to user input. They can be equipped with manipulators to allow for fine motor control, weapons to enhance combat efficacy, or specialty tools.
